misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.hasNext() and sc.hasNextInt() can be used to check if the user has provided input for a specific field in real-time and, if no input is present on the current line, the program can immediately fall into an 'else' block to provide a default value (like an empty string or 0).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's Scanner, methods like hasNext() and hasNextInt() are blocking operations when used with System.in. They do not return false simply because the user hasn't typed anything yet; instead, the program pauses and waits for the user to provide a token or for the input stream to be closed (EOF). This makes the 'else' logic for default values unreachable during normal interactive use.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: When the program is run interactively, it will hang and wait for input at the 'if' condition rather than executing the 'else' branch if the user leaves a field blank.

evidence.code_snippet: if (sc.hasNext()) { String tempName = sc.next(); names[i] = tempName; } else { names[i] = ""; }
if (sc.hasNextInt()) { int tempScore = sc.nextInt(); scores[j] = tempScore; } else { scores[j] = 0; }

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if sc.hasNextInt() returns false because the next token is not an integer, the Scanner will automatically skip or discard that invalid token before the next iteration of the loop.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: When a Scanner's 'has' check fails due to a type mismatch, the offending token is not consumed. It remains at the front of the input buffer. Subsequent calls to hasNextInt() will repeatedly look at the same invalid token and return false, resulting in all remaining indices of the array being filled with the default value.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If a user enters a non-integer (e.g., a name) where an integer score is expected, the loop will effectively 'freeze' on that token, and every remaining score in the array will be set to 0 without further reading from the user.

evidence.code_snippet: if (sc.hasNextInt()) { int tempScore = sc.nextInt(); scores[j] = tempScore; } else { scores[j] = 0; }

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that even after an array has been initialized and every index has been explicitly assigned a value (either a valid token or an empty string) through a loop, the elements might still contain a null value.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student lacks confidence in the deterministic nature of their own control flow and assignment. In Java, once a String array element is assigned a non-null value (including the empty string ""), it cannot spontaneously return to being null. The student's manual null check ignores the guarantee provided by their previous loop logic.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code contains unnecessary conditional checks that do not affect functionality but indicate a lack of trust in the notional machine's state tracking.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if a Scanner check like hasNextInt() returns false, the program can simply skip the assignment and the Scanner will automatically move past the 'invalid' token to the next one in the subsequent loop iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's Scanner, hasNextX() and nextX() methods are distinct in their consumption of the input buffer. nextInt() consumes a token, but hasNextInt() only 'peeks' at it. If the token is not an integer, it remains at the front of the buffer. Failing to consume it (e.g., by calling sc.next()) results in the Scanner 'stalling' on that same invalid token for all future attempts to read.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that even after a loop has explicitly iterated through every index of an array (0 to N-1) and assigned a value to each, there is still a possibility that elements (specifically the last element) might be null.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not fully realize that a for-loop bounded by the array's length that provides a value for every branch (the if/else on lines 27-33) guarantees a non-null state for all indices of a String array. The check on line 73 is logically unreachable given the preceding input loops.
